question: Fear creates fear, sir. I will not punish my people for their beliefs. Only for their deeds. am assured that the people of England love their Queen. My constant endeavour is to earn that love.
answer: The people are agitated.

question: What people?
answer: Your bishops are preaching that God is showing his displeasure- the Queen being still unmarried - some are saying infertile -

question: What nonsense!
answer: Dangerous nonsense. Mary Stuart has a son -

question: Why does everyone torment me with
answer: So long as you have no issue. Elizabeth looks back at Wsalsingham. Produce an heir and there'll be no more talk of Mary Stuart.

question: This is so pretty I'm inclined to send it as a present to my dear cousin Elizabeth. She holds up the delicate work to show her ladies. It is an intimate garment, of course. But even Elizabeth must have the occasional intimate moment. Annette reaches her mistress and kneels before her, holding out the letter.
answer: My Queen.

question: Our friends write to give us hope.
answer: Soon England's true believers will rise up against the bastard usurper Elizabeth, and slit her throat, and throw her down to hell.

question: That's enough, Annette. Slit her throat? Please.
answer: And when the bastard usurper is dead, my lady will be queen.

question: Here's my noble jailer, come to smack my hand. She holds out one hand to be smacked. The other hand holds the letter out of sight. Have I sinned again, sir?
answer: No, no, my lady. Unless beauty is counted a sin.

question: Oh, you jailer. I don't trust you.
answer: Not jailer, my lady, please. Warden. Protector. Friend. You are the Queen's guest. Mary signs to her ladies. One of them brings her the embroidery, discreetly receiving in exchange the hidden letter.

question: See how I pass my time in my lonely prison.
answer: Charming, ma'am. Distractingly charming. She holds the intimate garment against her body. Paulet seems to be too fascinated by it to notice he is being

question: She spoke to me. You have to give me that.
answer: Oh, I do. The Queen spoke to you. One word - but she spoke.

question: Two words.
answer: You're made. A dukedom at the very least.

question: Late again, Bess.
answer: I beg your majesty's forgiveness.

question: Given. Once.
answer: The puddle man is outside, majesty.

question: Well, sir. Who are you?
answer: Walter Raleigh, your majesty.

question: Ah, yes. Raleigh. I've heard of your voyage. What's your rank?
answer: A gentleman of Devon.

question: What do you want?
answer: The honour to be in the presence of my Queen, whose radiant beauty is the boast and glory of the English people.

question: Virginia? And if I marry? Will you change the name to Conjugia?
answer: I ask for your gracious permission, majesty, to return to the New World with your royal warrant, to found a colony under the laws and protections of England.

question: Who are they?
answer: Americans, majesty. They long to be your newest subjects.

question: Have they no ruler of their own?
answer: None to match England's Queen.

question: These gentlemen are welcome. See that they're treated well.
answer: I also come bearing gifts for your majesty, from the New World.

question: Continue.
answer: Gold. You spend it. Very satisfying. Courtesy of a Spanish ship, that found itself unable to complete its journey.

question: The fruits of piracy after all, it seems.
answer: Philip of Spain is no friend of England, majesty. The more gold I take from him, the safer you will be.

question: Well, well. A political pirate. A logic-chopping pirate.
answer: And your majesty's most loyal subject.

question: But not my best dressed. W elcome home, Mr Raleigh.
answer: What did you think of her?

question: William!
answer: Hello, Francis.

question: You look terrible. Don't they feed you in Paris? How are your studies? Learned the secrets of the universe yet?
answer: Not yet.

question: These are dangerous times to be questioning the ways of God. You must take care of yourself.
answer: My needs are simple.

question: You'll dine with us? You'll lodge with us?
answer: Look at you! All grown up.

question: Have you spoken to the Queen?
answer: I speak to her daily.

question: You know what I mean. You've done enough. No man could do more.
answer: I can't leave court yet. The Queen needs me.

question: So you're to die in harness like a pack horse, are you? And for what? Mary! William!
answer: These are difficult times-

question: It's always difficult times. Mary joins them, her arm in William's. Walsingham seizes the opportunity to change the subject.
answer: William, come and tell us all the new ideas in the University. Will the great breach in the church ever be healed?

question: Truth will always hate falsehood, ma'am.
answer: Why do we have to talk about war? Tell us your nice news, William. Are you married yet?

question: Not yet.
answer: Then we must find you a nice sensible English wife.

question: That depends what you propose to do with them.
answer: The pirate is not too bored by the vanities of the court, I hope.

question: A simple sailor, dazzled by the bright lights.
answer: If you can bring yourself to leave the dazzle of the bright lights for a moment - That can only mean the Queen.

question: I don't presume to raise my eyes so high.
answer: It seems you've presumed after all.

question: It seems you're determined to think the worst of me.
answer: Tell me what it is you really want.

question: What every man wants. Money. Fame. Love.
answer: In that order?

question: Each leads to the next. The money will buy and equip ships for a return voyage to the New World. The success of my infant colony there will make me famous. The fame will bring me love.
answer: It seems rather a long way round.

question: There are benefits along the way. It is something, after all, to take a blank on the map and build there a shining city.
answer: Which you will no doubt name after yourself.

question: May I ask a question in return?
answer: Of course.

question: How am I to win the Queen's favour?
answer: Why should I tell you that, sir?

question: I've little enough to offer, I know. But whatever I have to give - ask, and it's yours.
answer: My advice to you is, say what you mean to say as plainly as possible. All men flatter the Queen in the hope of advancement. Pay her the compliment of truth.

question: I don't even know your name.
answer: Elizabeth Throckmorton.

question: A second Elizabeth.
answer: Everyone calls me Bess.

question: Everyone calls me Bess.
answer: His highness the Archduke informs me that my charms overwhelm him. He will retire to his private quarters to rest. He's a sweet boy. I don't want him hurt by your schemes. I suspect him of being a professional charmer. Am I right?

question: He is certainly charming, my lady.
answer: There are duller professions. And what is it he hopes to gain by his charms?

question: He hopes for glory in his New World. He dreams of building a shining city.
answer: Which I'm to pay for, no doubt. You like him, don't you?

question: It's refreshing to meet a man who looks to a world beyond the court.
answer: So it is. We shall let him come again.

question: The Warden? My Warden? What have you done now, you bad man? Sent away my laundress? How am I to have clean clothes? Or do
answer: That was not my motive, ma'am.

question: How am I to send my intimate letters?
answer: Through me.

question: And you will read them.
answer: With respectful admiration.

question: Am I to have no privacy?
answer: No. Beneath the charm, steel.

question: You disappoint me, sir.
answer: The Queen orders these measures for your protection.

question: The Queen! Am I not a Queen too? What if I wish to write a love letter? Is Elizabeth to be sent a copy? Is she so starved of lovers that she must feed on mine?
answer: The Queen grieved when your husband died, ma'am. As she grieved when your second husband

question: Tormentor! Is that Elizabeth's order too? That you torment and mock me? She turns to go, but stops before leaving the room They say she's a beautiful woman.
answer: I don't presume to comment on the Queen's person.

question: She's called the virgin queen. Why is that, sir? Can it be that My friend, forgive me. You are my friend, are you not?
answer: I am your servant, ma'am, and your admirer.

question: Mr. Raleigh. I like your immensities. Your ocean is an image of eternity, I think. Such great spaces make us small. Do we discover the New World, Mr Raleigh, or does the New World discover us?
answer: You speak like a true explorer.

question: I like you, Mr Raleigh.
answer: And I like you.

question: You know, of course, that when I like a man, I reward him.
answer: I have heard that.

question: And what have you to say about it? R
answer: Reward my mission, majesty, not me.

question: Is the mission not the man?
answer: Leave me free to like you in return. That can be my reward.

question: Go on.
answer: I think it must be hard for so great a Queen to know the simple pleasure of being liked for herself.

question: Now you become dull.
answer: Mine!

question: You have - the stronger horse. The Queen does not give way to others. Raleigh stops his horse. Elizabeth rides on up to him and then past him. Raleigh secretly spurs his horse. The horse springs forward, ahead of her.
answer: Whoa! Whoa! Forgive me, majesty. My horse doesn't know his place yet Elizabeth looks at him, amused, intrigued.

question: Have you ever known your place, Mr. Raleigh? She urges her horse forward, forcing Raleigh to catch up. I'm surprised you're not married yet.
answer: I'm a sailor, majesty.

question: And can sailors not be lovers? Ah, I see. You like love better
answer: Your majesty is not eager to be married?

question: When I marry, I marry for my country.
answer: Some...

question: You've yet to meet your equal? Raleigh hesitates. She understands him.
answer: I would want someone who knows me as I am. Now it is Elizabeth who hesitates. He understands her as well.

question: George! What's wrong? Is your father alright?
answer: He's old. He won't live long now. Thank you for coming, dear Bess.

question: I was worried. You must send me no more letters. You know what would happen if I was caught.
answer: I need your help.

question: Do you need more money?
answer: My father is a tired old man. We don't want to hide like this

question: You are known Papists.
answer: The Queen loves you. Speak to her.

question: I cannot betray the Queen.
answer: You are not betraying her. My

question: Don't put me in danger like this.
answer: Cousin Bess, we've known each other all our lives. I would do nothing to harm you.

question: I'm sorry.
answer: If they catch us, they will kill us. Our lives are in your hands.

question: Mr Raleigh. A word of advice. The Queen chooses to show you favour. You naturally wish to take advantage of that. Don't ask for too much.
answer: You think all I want is money.

question: I hope all you want is money.
answer: You think I'm a cynical adventurer, with little breeding and less education. You're wrong. I'm a cynical adventurer with little breeding and an excellent education.

question: No, don't stop. I like it. Is it true, Bess? That I've never known the simple pleasure of being liked for myself?
answer: I hope you believe that I like you for yourself, my lady.

question: Is anybody ever liked just for themselves? Are you? I doubt it. Men like you because you're pretty. And because you have the ear of the Queen.
answer: No doubt, my lady.

question: Him too. He likes you because he wants my favour. You do realise that?
answer: Yes, my lady.

question: There is always other business. But I have been waiting too. Walsingham enters.
answer: Majesty.

question: Yes, Walsingham?
answer: The traitor has talked, majesty. The traitor Throckmorton.

question: And Norfolk. Mary Stuart is to be set free, and placed on the English throne.
answer: I know nothing of any invasion plans.

question: I refer to this plan as the Enterprise of England. It should more accurately be called `la Empresa di Inglaterra', because it's a Spanish plan. The plan of your king, my one-time brother-in- law, Philip II, to attack my country. You will leave my presence, sir! Go back to Spain! Tell Philip that I don't fear him, or his priests, or his armies. Tell him if he wants to shake his little fist at us, we're ready to give him such a bite he'll wish he'd kept his hands in his pockets.
answer: You see a leaf fall, and you think you know which way the wind blows. But a wind is coming, madam, that will sweep away your pride.

question: The Queen has sent you to me.
answer: Yes -

question: Tell the Queen that I will
answer: The Queen asks me to assure you -

question: I need no assurances. I'm no courtier and never have been. I've lost my appetite for playing games that it seems I'm too stupid to understand.
answer: That is unfair -

question: You call me unfair!
answer: Let me speak! The Queen shouts at you once, and you sulk like a child. I thought you more of a man than that. And I thought you a better friend to the Queen. Her every move is watched by a hundred eyes. Assassins plot to kill her. Enemies prepare to overwhelm her country. And you say she's playing games? Raleigh is watching her as she speaks, and he's impressed.

question: Very well. What is my Queen's command?
answer: Go to her, sir. As her friend.

question: You ask permission to go.
answer: Yes, majesty.

question: You plan to return to the New World. To your colony. For two, or three, or four years.
answer: If your majesty grants me your royal warrant.

question: That is a long time.
answer: There's nothing left for me to do here. At sea I know what I'm to do, I know the risks, I know the rewards. Here -

question: But you're quite wrong. You are needed here. I have decided to appoint you Captain of my personal guard.
answer: Captain of your - !

question: Kneel. Rise, Sir Walter Raleigh. Well? You may express your gratitude.
answer: This is too great an honour.

question: If it's such an honour, why are you staring at your boots?
answer: You know why. He raises his eyes, but he still doesn't look at her.

question: Now you stare at the wall. Am I so old and hideous that you can't even look me in the face?
answer: Why do you talk like a fool when you're anything but a fool?

question: Oh! It's you!
answer: I'm sorry. I didn't mean to disturb you.

question: My prayer's done.
answer: Something has distressed you.

question: And I thought I prayed in silence.
answer: So you did.

question: A man was hanged today. A Papist. I knew him well. He was my cousin. He died because I gave information. I gave information to prove my loyalty. Because I was afraid.
answer: That's necessity. That's the world we live in.

question: He told me he wanted to change. Become part of the new England. I was afraid that he was lying to me. But what if - what if it was true? He sees the horror in her eyes, at the thought that she has sent an innocent man to his death. Tears rise to her eyes. What if I was his last hope? What if I was the one person he thought he could trust?
answer: If you knew him well, you will have sensed the truth.

question: I thought so.
answer: He was hoping to use you. You did There, now. He wipes away a tear from her cheek. In desperate need of comfort, she throws herself into his arms. He holds her We're all mortal, Bess. We do what we can. He strokes her cheek. She meets his eyes, filled with gratitude. She takes the hand that touches her face and moves it to her lips. She kisses it, still holding his eyes. He draws her back into his arms, and they kiss. Suddenly they're kissing eagerly, greedily, their long pent- up passion released at last.

question: The alignment of the planets is most unusual this year. Mars is due to take the ascendant three days after the anniversary of your birth - your majesty was born on September 7th - and I see that twelve days before the anniversary of your birth - He transfers his attention to a different, astronomical chart. - there will be a full moon - the moon which - - governs the fortunes of all princes of the female gender.
answer: Princes of the female gender.

question: I mean to say, a prince who is also a woman.
answer: Yes, Dr Dee. I am following you. So what does it all mean? Which empire is to rise, and which is to fall?

question: Elizabeth is mortal. The Queen will never die.
answer: You see, Francis? This is a mystery. He has no patience with mysteries. W

question: And yet mysteries have power. Have you not learned that?
answer: Francis. Leave us for a moment. And the private life of this prince of the female gender, Dr Dee? What do the stars foretell there? Or is this too a mystery?

question: These are matters of state, majesty.
answer: Do the stars not foretell matters of state?

question: For such a prediction, I must look in a different chart. Wonderful... Out of such suffering, to have forged such strength... You will need all your strength in days to come... And love... So much love... But you doubt yourself, my child... I've not seen fear in
answer: Have I reason to fear?

question: Something has weakened you... But I'm no prophet. I see no more than the shadows of ghosts.
answer: An art, not a science. I understand.

question: Let him throw you round, Bess. You can trust him.
answer: You like your ladies to jump at your command?

question: Sometimes. Do you think that wrong?
answer: No, no. You're the Queen. You are to be obeyed.

question: To tell you the truth, Mr Raleigh, there are times when I'm tired of being always in control.
answer: Nonsense.

question: What?
answer: You don't mean a word of it. You eat and drink control.

question: Do you say so? Bess, you must try a dance with Mr Raleigh. He's eager to show us his skill.
answer: No skill at all, majesty. I don't know the steps.

question: Oh, it's very simple. You stand like this, with your hands firmly clasped here - and when she jumps, on the eighth step, you swing her round - once, twice, three times - and you're back to the beginning. What could be simpler? So come, Mr Raleigh. Take your position. I am to be obeyed.
answer: As your majesty wishes.

question: This is the spark that will set England ablaze. Reston takes out pistols, and hands one to Ramsay, one to Babington. R It's me. William.
answer: Where have you been? We haven't seen you for days.

question: I met up with some old friends.
answer: From Paris, no doubt.

question: Yes.
answer: And now you've come back. Do you know, I can still remember the day you were born? I was eleven years old. And you, this helpless bundle. I looked at you in your crib, with your little wrinkled face, and I loved you from the first. I vowed then to look after you. I watched you grow up with your head in the clouds, always a dreamer. I couldn't follow you there. And now I've failed you, haven't I? Forgive me if I haven't loved you enough. Did you really think I didn't know? Was it for money? At least tell me you got a good price. What then? What would you murder your own brother for?

question: Eternal life.
answer: Eternal life. The bribe no man can refuse.

question: You bring news?
answer: The Queen has been attacked -

question: Yes?
answer: The assassin seized -

question: Yes?
answer: The Queen unharmed -

question: Unharmed?
answer: And you, ma'am, are under arrest.

question: Me? What has any of this to do with me?
answer: My own invention. Theatrical, but effective. My master has every letter you've written.

question: Your master?
answer: Walsingham.

question: Why was the gun not loaded?
answer: To kill the Queen. You know it. You know everything.

question: Not quite everything.
answer: I've told you all I know. Go ahead and kill me. Take what's left of me. I don't care any more. All my life you've had everything and I've had nothing. So finish it. There's a better world waiting for me. We'll all be judged in the end, brother. Even you.

question: They say she's taller than me. Her hair is chestnut in colour. Her eyes are hazel. They say she's beautiful. But people lie. They say I am beautiful. A dismissive shrug. Clearly she does not think herself beautiful.
answer: She plotted to kill you.

question: Yes, it's true. I've read her letters. I too was a prisoner
answer: So do we all.

question: I can be merciful. But she
answer: She'll go on lying til you cut

question: You used to be gentler, Bess.
answer: I used to be quieter, majesty.

question: My Queen.
answer: My friend. Did Bess bid you come? Have you

question: No. You don't need me to instruct you in your duty.
answer: My duty? Was it my father's duty to murder my mother? I would be

question: Since when were you so afraid?
answer: Yes, I am afraid. I am always afraid.

question: You fear your soul will be touched. Royalty is close to immortality. Kill a Queen - and queens are mortal.
answer: You understand me well.

question: We mortals have many weaknesses. We feel too much. Hurt too much. And all too soon, we die. But we do have the chance of love.
answer: Do we? Do we really? I owe England my life. Don't ask for my soul.

question: Philip of Spain is a God-fearing man. He cannot make war without just cause. He sent the Jesuit to kill a Queen. But not you.
answer: Not me!

question: The Jesuit's mission was to draw Mary Stuart into the murder plot. He knew I was reading her every letter. He waited until she wrote the words that sealed her guilt.
answer: And I ordered her execution. I murdered God's anointed Queen. And now God's most dutiful son makes holy war to punish me.

question: Forgive me, majesty. Let me go.
answer: Yes... Go... `Think you that there is any certainty in the affairs of mankind, when you know that one swift hour can destroy the greatest among us?' Boethius.

question: Yes... Go... `Think you that there is any certainty in the affairs of mankind, when you know that one swift hour can destroy the greatest among us?' Boethius.
answer: The Consolation of Philosophy.

question: Thank you for coming at this late hour. We're at war. Who knows when we'll meet again. If we'll meet again.
answer: May the Lord God preserve England's Queen.

question: The same God in whose name Philip wages his holy war. Philip is a righteous man, and righteous men love to destroy. They burn whole worlds to make them pure, and leave behind - ashes.
answer: He'll not burn England.

question: He may. His Armada is invincible, they say. If London falls, I fall. If England is lost, I am lost.
answer: Never!

question: Never? It's night. My thoughts turn dark. Don't you ever think that one day, perhaps one day soon, you too will die?
answer: The closer I come to death, the more I want to live. The hungrier I am for life.

question: Why be afraid of tomorrow? Today's all we have, and all we know.
answer: Today. Tonight.

question: Now.
answer: I wish -

question: I've never known a woman like you.
answer: In some other time, in some other world, could you have loved me?

question: I know only one world. In this world, I have loved you.
answer: Then there's... something you could do for me - something I've not known for a very long time - if you felt so inclined -

question: I'll be quick. I have something to tell you. But I ask for nothing. Is that understood? Your life is your own. Nothing will change.
answer: What is this, Bess?

question: I'm -
answer: You're pregnant?

question: To my mother's house.
answer: You can't go!

question: I'm a ward of the Queen. I can't court a man without her permission. I can't marry without her permission. As for having a child -
answer: When were you planning to leave?

question: As soon as I'm allowed.
answer: Am I not to see you again? What's to become of the child? Bess -

question: Hush! We've no choice. You know it as well as I do.
answer: All I know is nothing's as it should be.

question: Please listen. You once said to me, `Whatever I have to give, ask and it's yours.' Do you remember?
answer: Of course I remember.

question: I ask that you forget me. Go to your ship. Do your duty. Forget me.
answer: Oh, Bess...

question: This Spanish Armada is at sea carrying an army of ten thousand men. The Duke of Parma has fifteen thousand men on the French coast.
answer: They plan to cross the Channel in barges, under the protection of the Spanish fleet, and sail up the Thames.

question: But they don't yet have enough barges at Calais. We have a little time.
answer: That is so.

question: Where is she? Bess! Bess Throckmorton! Bess comes running from the far end.
answer: Here, my lady!

question: Tell me! Is it true? Are you married? Are you with child? Are you WITH CHILD? Bess stands before her with her head bowed.
answer: Yes, my lady. Elizabeth falls on her with uncontrolled rage, striking out at her, beating her about the head, shrieking out the words

question: I know it, old friend. Don't leave me now. You always did do as you pleased, whether I wanted it or not. I've no doubt you'll do as you please now. When was the birth? The mother is well?
answer: Thank God.

question: And the child?
answer: My son is well.

question: Your Elizabeth has a child. You must be proud.
answer: Yes.

question: And fulfilled?
answer: As any man can be. Elizabeth looks at him in silence for a long moment.
